elements.content: Adenine presents an interesting preformed natural heterocyclic skeleton to bind metal ions with well-defined angles with the possibility of multisite intraligand coordination to afford a myriad of complex architectures. This article describes crafting of additional coordination sites by introducing a Schiff base linkage on adenine nucleobase. As envisaged, this approach will expand opportunities for the construction of dynamic self-assembled, metal-assisted frameworks on the adenine platform. Based on crystal studies, we find that ligand (HL) affords ML2 type coordination with Cd(II) and M2L2 type complexes with Zn(II) and Co(II), while presenting a linear 1D polymeric structure with Cu(II) ions. Interestingly, Ag(I) hydrolyzed the imine bond to afford interconnected metallacycles. Photophysical properties of Cd and Zn complexes exhibited enhanced fluorescence compared with the ligand alone.

elements.content: Substituted adenine and other nucleobases are versatile natural heterocyclic ligands, which can support a number of metal coordination modes and reveal formation of discrete coordination complexes as well as polymeric structures. In addition, other noncovalent interactions such as hydrogen bonding and π–π stacking are also invoked to stabilize the crystal lattice of metal–nucleobase complex self-assembled architectures, which also exhibit promising applications. Much of the structural chemistry described in the literature with nucleobase ligands is ascribed to their nature, purine or pyrimidine, and also to the presence of ancillary groups appended to the skeleton, either at terminal or at bridging sites. Inevitably, metal coordinated systems also show immense potential as material precursors, as drug precursors and in other applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Substituted adenine and other nucleobases are versatile natural heterocyclic ligands, which can support a number of metal coordination modes and reveal formation of discrete coordination complexes as well as polymeric structures. In addition, other noncovalent interactions such as hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking are also invoked to stabilize the crystal lattice of metal-nucleobase complex self-assembled architectures, which also exhibit promising applications. Much of the structural chemistry described in the literature with nucleobase ligands is ascribed to their nature, purine or pyrimidine, and also to the presence of ancillary groups appended to the skeleton, either at terminal or at bridging sites. Inevitably, metal coordinated systems also show immense potential as material precursors, as drug precursors and in other applications.

elements.content: Nitschke and others have described subcomponent self-assembly for construction of intricate, metal-assisted architectures using two simple building block principles: (i) use of dynamic-covalent Schiff base ligand (CN) and (ii) invoking metal coordination (N → M) during subcomponent ligation reaction. Subcomponent assembly has provided new breakthroughs in ligand design and in evolution of emergent functions. In addition, it is also shown that thermodynamic control of systems employing dynamic combinatorial/covalent chemistry afford formation of self-sorting and self-replicating systems, which could serve as models to understand, mimic, and modulate complex biological systems.

Subcomponent assembly has provided new breakthroughs in ligand design and in evolution of emergent functions. In addition, it is also shown that thermodynamic control of systems employing dynamic combinatorial/covalent chemistry afford formation of self-sorting and self-replicating systems, which could serve as models to understand, mimic, and modulate complex biological systems.

elements.content: Introduction of additional metal ion binding sites to afford chelate-tethered nucleobase is an established strategy to augment coordination potential of nucleobases. To expand the coordination sites in adenine and to test the possibility of having a Schiff base linkage in modified nucleobase, we decided to attach an amino pendant group at N9 position to synthesize a multifunctional ligand (HL) (Figure ), as an alternative to in situ generated Schiff base. This ligand was expected to offer two new coordination sites, N12 and O1, in addition to N1, N7, N3, and N6. This design also expected to involve N3 nitrogen for coordination through a fold-back chelating arm, which is otherwise a less preferred site for metal coordination.

To expand the coordination sites in adenine and to test the possibility of having a Schiff base linkage in modified nucleobase, we decided to attach an amino pendant group at N9 position to synthesize a multifunctional ligand (HL) (Figure ), as an alternative to in situ generated Schiff base. This ligand was expected to offer two new coordination sites, N12 and O1, in addition to N1, N7, N3, and N6. This design also expected to involve N3 nitrogen for coordination through a fold-back chelating arm, which is otherwise a less preferred site for metal coordination.

elements.content: Adenine based dipolar imine-phenol ligand, HL.
elements.clean_text: 1  Adenine based dipolar imine-phenol ligand, HL.

elements.content: This design is in continuation to our efforts to create adenine-based ligands to study molecular architecture of metal complexes, catalysis, surface adsorption, gas storage, and bioimaging applications. Continuing our work, we anticipated interesting hierarchical coordination features arising out of ligand HL owing to multiple metal interaction sites and due to the possibility of fold-back geometry (Figure ).

elements.content: 1H and 13C NMR spectra were obtained on a JEOL-DELTA2 500 model spectrometer operating at 500 MHz. The spectra were recorded in DMSO-d 6 solution, and the chemical shifts were referenced with respect to tetramethylsilane. High resolution (ESI+ mode) mass spectra were obtained on Waters, Q-Tof Premier Micro mass HAB 213 mass spectrometer, Department of Chemistry, IIT Kanpur, India. All solvents were distilled prior to use by using standard procedures. 2-Bromoethylamine hydrobromide (98% purity) was purchased from Avra synthesis Pvt. Ltd., Nacharam, Hyderabad, India; salicylaldehyde was purchased from Sisco Research Laboratories Pvt. Ltd., Mumbai, India. Silver and copper nitrate were purchased from Spectrochem Pvt. Ltd., Mumbai, India, while adenine, cadmium nitrate, cobalt chloride, zinc nitrate, and potassium carbonate were purchased from SD Fine Chemicals Pvt. Ltd., Mumbai, India, and used without further purification. All the crystals were grown by slow evaporation method except the silver complex, which was grown by solvent diffusion.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

 1H and 13C NMR spectra were obtained on a JEOL-DELTA2 500 model spectrometer operating at 500 MHz. The spectra were recorded in DMSO-d 6 solution, and the chemical shifts were referenced with respect to tetramethylsilane. High resolution (ESI+ mode) mass spectra were obtained on Waters, Q-Tof Premier Micro mass HAB 213 mass spectrometer, Department of Chemistry, IIT Kanpur, India. All solvents were distilled prior to use by using standard procedures. 2-Bromoethylamine hydrobromide (98% purity) was purchased from Avra synthesis Pvt. Ltd., Nacharam, Hyderabad, India; salicylaldehyde was purchased from Sisco Research Laboratories Pvt. Ltd., Mumbai, India. Silver and copper nitrate were purchased from Spectrochem Pvt. Ltd., Mumbai, India, while adenine, cadmium nitrate, cobalt chloride, zinc nitrate, and potassium carbonate were purchased from SD Fine Chemicals Pvt. Ltd., Mumbai, India, and used without further purification. All the crystals were grown by slow evaporation method except the silver complex, which was grown by solvent diffusion.

elements.content: The reaction of Cd(NO3)2 (0.163 g, 0.05 mmol) and ligand HL (0.03 g, 0.10 mmol) in methanol gave a clear solution, which under slow evaporation for 2–3 days gave single crystals of 1 (32% yield). HRMS [L + Cd]+ calculated 395.0184, found 395.0194; [2L + Cd + H]+ calculated 677.1414, found 677.1422. elements.content: In a 25 mL round-bottomed flask, ligand HL (0.03 g, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (2 mL) followed by addition of acetonitrile solution of AgNO3 (0.03 g, 0.21 mmol, 1 mL). Then the reaction was stirred for 12 h at room temperature. The resulting clear solution yielded colorless crystals in a week by the solvent diffusion method with pet ether, which were isolated and dried under high vacuum (31% yield). HRMS [AA + Ag]+ calculated 285.0018, found 285.0028. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3326.56(b), 3187.97(b), 1651.49(s), 1605.38(s), 1572.21(s), 1489.18(s), 1364.00(m), 1247.82(m), 1122.02(m), 1059.61(m), 714.00(m), 645.07(m).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [C14H24N16O14Ag2] (5)

In a 25 mL round-bottomed flask, ligand HL (0.03 g, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (2 mL) followed by addition of acetonitrile solution of AgNO3 (0.03 g, 0.21 mmol, 1 mL). Then the reaction was stirred for 12 h at room temperature. The resulting clear solution yielded colorless crystals in a week by the solvent diffusion method with pet ether, which were isolated and dried under high vacuum (31% yield). HRMS [AA + Ag]+ calculated 285.0018, found 285.0028. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3326.56(b), 3187.97(b), 1651.49(s), 1605.38(s), 1572.21(s), 1489.18(s), 1364.00(m), 1247.82(m), 1122.02(m), 1059.61(m), 714.00(m), 645.07(m).

elements.clean_text:
Procedure for Measurement of Fluorescence Data

Solid-state photoexcitation and emission spectra were recorded using double UV-vis-NIR spectrophotometer (Varian model Cary 5000) and Jobin Yvon Horiba Fluorolog-3 spectrofluorimeter, when excited at 320 nm wavelength at room temperature.

elements.content: Pale yellow crystals of ligand HL were grown from its methanolic solution. Closer inspection of diffraction data suggested that crystals belonged to the monoclinic system in P21/c space group (Table ). The asymmetric unit contained one ligand molecule (Figure a) with short intramolecular hydrogen bonding between N12(CN)···H–O (Table S3, ), and the crystal lattice was additionally stabilized by purine–purine interactions through Hoogsteen and Watson–Crick faces, which gave rise to one-dimensional polymer (Figure b).
elements.clean_text:
Result and Discussion

Crystal Structure of Ligand, HL 

Pale yellow crystals of ligand HL were grown from its methanolic solution. Closer inspection of diffraction data suggested that crystals belonged to the monoclinic system in P21/c space group (Table ). The asymmetric unit contained one ligand molecule (Figure a) with short intramolecular hydrogen bonding between N12(CN)⋅⋅⋅H-O (Table S3, ), and the crystal lattice was additionally stabilized by purine-purine interactions through Hoogsteen and Watson-Crick faces, which gave rise to one-dimensional polymer (Figure b).

Pale yellow colored crystals of 1 were grown from methanolic solution of HL and Cd(NO3)2 in a ratio of 1:2. Crystal refinement data suggested that 1 belonged to the monoclinic system, with I2/a space group (Table ). The asymmetric unit comprised two HL ligands as anions L, a Cd (II) ion, and two water molecules (Figure a). The Schiff base entity offered oxygen O1, N3, and N12 nitrogens for cadmium(II) coordination, thereby behaving as a hexadentate species, thus leading to the formation of a distorted octahedral mononuclear cadmium center (Table ).

Discrete ML2 geometry clearly established our premise of adenine modification where Cd was able to interact in the binding pocket created by the Schiff base and additionally recruited the N3 nitrogen through an intramolecular coordination mode. Notably, purine–purine interaction in the crystal lattice offered stability through the Watson–Crick face (Figure b) forming a one-dimensional zigzag structure. Stability of the crystal lattice is further enhanced by water molecules due to intermolecular hydrogen bonding as N6–H···O(W2), resulting in a two-dimensional structure (Figure c). Selected bond distances, bond angles, and hydrogen bonding of complex 1 are given in Tables S1, S2, and S3, respectively, .

Crystal refinement data of 2 suggested that it belonged to the triclinic system in P1 space group. elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Analysis of Complex 2 

Pale yellow colored crystals were grown by slow evaporation from equimolar methanolic solutions of HL and Zn(NO3)2. Crystal refinement data of 2 suggested that it belonged to the triclinic system in P1 space group. The asymmetric unit consisted of HL ligand as an anion L, coordinated to Zn ion and further coordinated to nitrate ion. One methanol and one water molecule were also present as noncoordinated molecules.

elements.content: The coordination sphere around the zinc ion involved the N3 ring nitrogen, N12 side chain imino nitrogen, two oxygen atoms from two anions of HL, and a nitrate ion. This arrangement afforded a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry (Figure b), which led to a dinuclear cluster where two purine rings were aligned opposite to each other. Intermolecular hydrogen bonding also stabilized 2 resulting in a one-dimensional zigzag structure (Figure c).

elements.content: Pink crystals of 3 were grown by reacting ligand HL and CoCl2 from their acetonitrilic solution by slow crystallization. Crystal refinement data suggested that 3 belonged to triclinic system with P1̅ space group. The asymmetric unit of 3 consisted of a Co(II) ion, a ligand molecule as an anion L, and one free acetonitrile molecule. The overall charge was neutralized by a Cl– anion present in the unit cell. The Co(II) ion coordinated to the N3 ring imino nitrogen, the N12 side chain nitrogen, two oxygen atoms from two anionic ligands L, and two chloride ions, leading to formation of a dinuclear cluster with distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry (Figure a).

elements.content: Reaction of Cu(NO3)2 with HL in methanol gave a clear green color solution, which afforded green crystals by slow evaporation method. Refinement data suggested that 4 belonged to an orthorhombic system with Pbca space group. The asymmetric unit of 4 consisted of one Cu atom coordinated to an anion of HL (Figure a), while the charge was balanced by one nitrate. One noncoordinated water and ethanol molecule were also present. Closer inspection of the lattice revealed that the Cu ion was pentacoordinated to nitrate, N3, N7, N12, and O1 of HL to give distorted square pyramidal geometry (Figure S2a, ).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Analysis of Complex 4 

Reaction of Cu(NO3)2 with HL in methanol gave a clear green color solution, which afforded green crystals by slow evaporation method. Refinement data suggested that 4 belonged to an orthorhombic system with Pbca space group. The asymmetric unit of 4 consisted of one Cu atom coordinated to an anion of HL (Figure a), while the charge was balanced by one nitrate. One noncoordinated water and ethanol molecule were also present. Closer inspection of the lattice revealed that the Cu ion was pentacoordinated to nitrate, N3, N7, N12, and O1 of HL to give distorted square pyramidal geometry (Figure S2a, ).

elements.content: The crystal packing structure showed that it formed a two-dimensional supramolecular framework, via hydrogen bonding, through water molecules present in the lattice. N6–H···O(w) and O–H(w)···N1 H-bonding were observed through the Watson–Crick face. Moreover, intramolecular H-bonding also stabilized the structure by N6–H···O1 interaction (Figure d). Additionally, further stabilization of the crystal lattice arises from π–π stacking interactions between the phenyl rings of HL with a centroid distance of 3.52(5) Å (Figure d).

Additionally, further stabilization of the crystal lattice arises from π-π stacking interactions between the phenyl rings of HL with a centroid distance of 3.52(5) Å (Figure d).

elements.content: Colorless crystals of 5 were grown in acetonitrile and pet ether by solvent diffusion method, and crystal refinement data suggested that it belonged to the monoclinic system in P21/c space group (Table ). Curiously, an unusual hydrolysis reaction occurred yielding the corresponding adenine amine (AA) (Figure ), which afforded 5 through a tridentate coordination with the help of N1, N7, and N12 nitrogens in a distorted tetrahedral geometry (Figure S2b, ). The presence of water molecules aiding hydrolysis could be attributed to the hygroscopic nature of solvent. The asymmetric unit of 5 was composed of hydrolyzed adenine amine coordinated to a silver ion (Figure a) and two nitrate ions and one noncoordinated water and methanol molecule.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Analysis of Complex 5 

Colorless crystals of 5 were grown in acetonitrile and pet ether by solvent diffusion method, and crystal refinement data suggested that it belonged to the monoclinic system in P21/c space group (Table ). Curiously, an unusual hydrolysis reaction occurred yielding the corresponding adenine amine (AA) (Figure ), which afforded 5 through a tridentate coordination with the help of N1, N7, and N12 nitrogens in a distorted tetrahedral geometry (Figure S2b, ). The presence of water molecules aiding hydrolysis could be attributed to the hygroscopic nature of solvent. The asymmetric unit of 5 was composed of hydrolyzed adenine amine coordinated to a silver ion (Figure a) and two nitrate ions and one noncoordinated water and methanol molecule.

elements.content: Hydrolysis of Schiff base is a functionally relevant biochemical reaction, which can be effected by divalent ions. However, a similar hydrolytic reaction using monovalent ion Ag+ has received less attention. This imine bond with phenol moiety is stable because of intramolecular hydrogen bonding between N12 and OH of the phenol moiety, which protects the imine bond from hydrolysis.
elements.clean_text: Hydrolysis of Schiff base is a functionally relevant biochemical reaction, which can be effected by divalent ions. However, a similar hydrolytic reaction using monovalent ion Ag+ has received less attention. This imine bond with phenol moiety is stable because of intramolecular hydrogen bonding between N12 and OH of the phenol moiety, which protects the imine bond from hydrolysis.

elements.content: Coordination to three nitrogens (N1, N3, and N12) lead to the formation of a two-dimensional sheet-like architecture in the lattice (Figure b), with embedded dimeric (Figure c) and tetrameric interconnected metallacycles (Figure d). Notably, the metallacyclic quartet consisted of two N1–Ag and four N7–Ag interactions, each with bond lengths of 2.30(3) and 2.27(5) Å, respectively. Two additional N12–Ag1 interactions of bond length 2.23(3) Å and π–π stacking with the distance 3.68(0) Å, also provide necessary stabilization. The dimeric metallacycle requires only two N1–Ag and two N12–Ag interactions. Each silver ion was part of three metallacycles, two tetrameric metallacycles and one dimeric metallacycle, in the supramolecular architecture.
elements.clean_text: Coordination to three nitrogens (N1, N3, and N12) lead to the formation of a two-dimensional sheet-like architecture in the lattice (Figure b), with embedded dimeric (Figure c) and tetrameric interconnected metallacycles (Figure d). Notably, the metallacyclic quartet consisted of two N1-Ag and four N7-Ag interactions, each with bond lengths of 2.30(3) and 2.27(5) Å, respectively. Two additional N12-Ag1 interactions of bond length 2.23(3) Å and π-π stacking with the distance 3.68(0) Å, also provide necessary stabilization. The dimeric metallacycle requires only two N1-Ag and two N12-Ag interactions. Each silver ion was part of three metallacycles, two tetrameric metallacycles and one dimeric metallacycle, in the supramolecular architecture.

elements.content: We investigated solid state fluorescence of ligand HL along with complexes 1–5 at room temperature (Figure ). Ligand HL exhibited weak fluorescence at ∼431 nm when excited at 320 nm wavelength, which could be attributed to intraligand π–π* emission. While there is an enhancement of fluorescence with Cd2+ and Zn2+ d10 metal ions, there is a slight quenching in case of Cu2+ ions, which could be due to spin–orbit coupling, electron transfer, or ligand to metal energy transfer. Enhancement with d10 metal ions could be ascribed to increase in fluorescence without introducing low-energy metal centered or charge separated excited states into the complexes, so that electron transfer processes cannot occur easily.

Ligand HL exhibited weak fluorescence at ~431 nm when excited at 320 nm wavelength, which could be attributed to intraligand π-π* emission. While there is an enhancement of fluorescence with Cd2+ and Zn2+ d10 metal ions, there is a slight quenching in case of Cu2+ ions, which could be due to spin-orbit coupling, electron transfer, or ligand to metal energy transfer. Enhancement with d10 metal ions could be ascribed to increase in fluorescence without introducing low-energy metal centered or charge separated excited states into the complexes, so that electron transfer processes cannot occur easily.

elements.content: We have studied the coordination behavior of adenine Schiff base with transition metals such as Zn(II), Cd(II), Co(II), Cu(II), and Ag(I) by X-ray crystallography. This adenine Schiff base got hydrolyzed in the presence of Ag(I) to give adenine amine, which finally coordinated with adenine amine to give a 2D supramolecular architecture; this Schiff base hydrolysis has significance in biology. It gave a 1D polymeric structure with Cu(II), while with Zn(II) and Co(II), it gave M2L2 complexes, and with Cd(II) it gave a ML2 complex. There is enhancement in fluorescence in case of d10 metal ions in comparison to adenine Schiff base.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have studied the coordination behavior of adenine Schiff base with transition metals such as Zn(II), Cd(II), Co(II), Cu(II), and Ag(I) by X-ray crystallography. This adenine Schiff base got hydrolyzed in the presence of Ag(I) to give adenine amine, which finally coordinated with adenine amine to give a 2D supramolecular architecture; this Schiff base hydrolysis has significance in biology. It gave a 1D polymeric structure with Cu(II), while with Zn(II) and Co(II), it gave M2L2 complexes, and with Cd(II) it gave a ML2 complex. There is enhancement in fluorescence in case of d10 metal ions in comparison to adenine Schiff base.

HRMS [L + Co + Cl + H]+ calculated 376.0250, found 376.0259. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3392.66(b), 1660.73(m), 1626.82(s), 1603.50(m), 1487.69(s), 1423.88(s), 1361.24(s), 1299.36(m), 1222.95(m), 849.14(s), 792.93(s).

The reaction of Cu(NO3)2 (0.51 g, 0.21 mmol) with ligand HL (0.03 g, 0.10 mmol) in methanol under slow evaporation afforded green crystals of 4 (45% yield). HRMS [L + Cu]+ calculated 344.0447, found 344.0448. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3640.14(m), 3430.33(b), 3145.86(b), 1660.68(s), 1627.93(s), 1595.62(m), 1575.01(s), 1548.29(s), 1475.77(s), 1384.36(s), 1293.30(s), 1197.40(s), 1153.39(s), 1018.66(s), 910.11(s), 797.78(s), 769.88(s).

Synthesis of [C<sub>14</sub>H<sub>24</sub>N<sub>16</sub>O<sub>14</sub>Ag<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>5</bold>)

In a 25 mL round-bottomed flask, ligand HL (0.03 g, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (2 mL) followed by addition of acetonitrile solution of AgNO3 (0.03 g, 0.21 mmol, 1 mL). Then the reaction was stirred for 12 h at room temperature. The resulting clear solution yielded colorless crystals in a week by the solvent diffusion method with pet ether, which were isolated and dried under high vacuum (31% yield). HRMS [AA + Ag]+ calculated 285.0018, found 285.0028. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3326.56(b), 3187.97(b), 1651.49(s), 1605.38(s), 1572.21(s), 1489.18(s), 1364.00(m), 1247.82(m), 1122.02(m), 1059.61(m), 714.00(m), 645.07(m).

Synthesis of [C16H16ClN7OCo] (3)

An equimolar reaction of ligand HL (0.03 g, 0.10 mmol) and CoCl2 (0.25 g, 0.10 mmol) in methanol gave a violet colored solution, which under slow evaporation for a week gave crystals of 3 (42% yield). HRMS [L + Co + Cl + H]+ calculated 376.0250, found 376.0259. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3392.66(b), 1660.73(m), 1626.82(s), 1603.50(m), 1487.69(s), 1423.88(s), 1361.24(s), 1299.36(m), 1222.95(m), 849.14(s), 792.93(s).

Synthesis of [C15H20N7O6Cu] (4)

The reaction of Cu(NO3)2 (0.51 g, 0.21 mmol) with ligand HL (0.03 g, 0.10 mmol) in methanol under slow evaporation afforded green crystals of 4 (45% yield). HRMS [L + Cu]+ calculated 344.0447, found 344.0448. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3640.14(m), 3430.33(b), 3145.86(b), 1660.68(s), 1627.93(s), 1595.62(m), 1575.01(s), 1548.29(s), 1475.77(s), 1384.36(s), 1293.30(s), 1197.40(s), 1153.39(s), 1018.66(s), 910.11(s), 797.78(s), 769.88(s).

Synthesis of [C14H24N16O14Ag2] (5)

In a 25 mL round-bottomed flask, ligand HL (0.03 g, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (2 mL) followed by addition of acetonitrile solution of AgNO3 (0.03 g, 0.21 mmol, 1 mL). Then the reaction was stirred for 12 h at room temperature. The resulting clear solution yielded colorless crystals in a week by the solvent diffusion method with pet ether, which were isolated and dried under high vacuum (31% yield). HRMS [AA + Ag]+ calculated 285.0018, found 285.0028. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3326.56(b), 3187.97(b), 1651.49(s), 1605.38(s), 1572.21(s), 1489.18(s), 1364.00(m), 1247.82(m), 1122.02(m), 1059.61(m), 714.00(m), 645.07(m).
